Christian Kohlschï¿½tter wrote:
> I have a humble question regarding the DecidingScope.
> Is there currently any way to *forcibly* accept or reject a URI regardless of 
> any downstream DecideRules?

Currently, no. Every rule gets a chance to pass or have its say, and
the last rule to give a decision wins.

> If I understand correctly, the DecideRuleSequence class currently iterates 
> over all DecideRules and adjusts the overall decision to the current 
> DecideRule's decision whenever that one is not "PASS". The problem is that 
> one really must carefully consider where to put a decide rule.

This is somewhat by design; careful choice of ordering was meant to
allow control over which rules trump/subset others.

> For example, adding a PrerequisiteAcceptDecideRule at the end of the sequence 
> will always result in ACCEPT for any prerequisite document, even if that 
> prerequisite's URI has been declared out of scope by upstream decide rules.

Usually, this is what's wanted -- since the mere fact that a
'prerequisite' has been discovered implies that it's needed
before fetching an otherwise in-scope URI. But, for novel
situations, a PrerequisiteAcceptDecideRule could be placed
earlier, or special overide-all exclude rules could be placed
after it.

> Wouldn't it make sense to offer the administrator some more control over these 
> rules by adding something like an ANDDecideRuleSequence (returns REJECT as 
> soon as it gets a REJECT) and an ORDecideRuleSequence (returns ACCEPT as soon 
> as it gets an ACCEPT)?

Yes, and similarly, we'd also kicked around the idea that rules could
include a 'and stop all further processing' option, which skips all
subsequent rules (making the current decision final).

I don't know if 'AND' and 'OR' would be the best names for the
sequence rules you describe, since the ACCEPT/REJECT/PASS logic
isn't strictly binary. RejectIfAny or AcceptIfAny could be
clearer. (You could also imagine a MajorityRules rule.)

However, we decided to put off such intricate rules, or any
concept of branching, until there was more experience with the
basic system and better confidence that the extra complexity
was needed. We haven't yet encountered a situation that can't
be handled with careful ordering of existing rules.

If you wanted to contribute such rules, it would be good to
accompany them with a practical example of a situation that
requires them.

- Gordon @ IA
